awd_titl_txt: Thermochemistry of Metal-Ligand Bonds (Singly and Multiply Charged) and Protonated Peptides
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics, and Mechanisms A (CSDM-A) program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Peter B. Armentrout and his students at the University of Utah are exploring the structure and reactivity of various molecules in the gas-phase, including metal cations (“cation” means positively charged) and complexes composed of metal cations and other molecules such as water (H2O), carbon monoxide (CO) and biologically relevant amino acids and peptides.   These studies are being conducted in the gas phase because it is important to understand the inherent structure and properties of these molecular systems, in other words in the absence of the countless water molecules they would encounter in an aqueous solution.   The Armentrout research group is actually developing new techniques to deliver charged molecules and complexes into the gas phase, either free of water or with a selected number of water molecules or other organic solvent molecules.  The research includes four main thrusts: how strongly bound are solvent molecules to doubly charged metals? How does the reactivity of a molecular ion change when its electrons are excited by laser light or collisions?  How do ionized peptides decompose, and what are the molecular structures of decomposition products? Such information is valuable in developing new catalytic systems, in understanding biological function (including effects on health), and in environmental remediation efforts. In all cases, these experimental studies are complemented by theoretical examinations of the same phenomena. Students engaged in this research project are gaining valuable experience in state-of-the-art physical and analytical methods, including a technique called guided ion beam mass spectrometry (GIBMS), and quantum mechanical calculations.

The research is conducted using two types of instrumentation. Thermodynamic experiments are enabled by using a guided ion beam tandem mass spectrometer that permits measurement of absolute reaction cross sections as a function of kinetic energy. This enables the direct measurement of the energies required for cationized peptides to decompose or for desolvation of metal dications or metal hydroxide cations. This apparatus is also being fitted with an ion mobility source that allows separation of metal cations in different electronic states or of different conformers of cationized peptides. This instrumental combination enables quantitative studies of spin-orbit coupling effects and direct measurements of the energetic differences between different conformers, both of which are potentially transformative studies. Structural studies involve the use of infrared multiple photon dissociation spectroscopy conducted at the FELIX facility in the Netherlands, which include experiments concerning cationized peptides and alkane activation by metal cations. Broader impacts of these studies include a better understanding of how to elicit sequence information in proteins, providing thermodynamic benchmarks for theory, and elucidating mechanistic information regarding transition metal catalysis, in addition to the educational aspects of involving both undergraduate and graduate students in a full range of experimental and theoretical work. A software package (CRUNCH) developed to obtain thermochemical information from the experiments is undergoing continuous updates and refinement and continues to be made available to other groups interested in mass spectrometry based thermodynamic measurements.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Project outcomes for National Science Foundation Grant CHE-1954142

In this project funded by the Chemical Structure Dynamics and Mechanism (CSDM-A) program of the Chemistry Division of the NSF, Professor Peter B. Armentrout and his students at the University of Utah have performed research that has been disseminated in 29 published papers and 32 invited seminars or contributed talks. Their work explores the structure and reactivity of various molecules in the gas-phase, including metal cations (“cation” means positively charged) and complexes composed of metal cations and other molecules such as water (H2O), methane (CH4), and biologically relevant amino acids and peptides. These studies are conducted in the gas phase because it is important to understand the inherent structure and properties of these molecular systems, in other words, in the absence of the countless water molecules they would encounter in an aqueous solution. The Armentrout research group is developing new techniques to deliver charged molecules and complexes into the gas phase, either free of water or with a selected number of water molecules or other organic solvent molecules and in a selected electronic state or selected structure. The research includes four main thrusts: What is the intrinsic reactivity of various metals? How strongly bound are solvent or biological molecules to metals? How do the properties of a molecular ion change when it is excited by laser light or collisions? How do ionized peptides decompose, and what are the molecular structures of the decomposition products? Such information is valuable in developing new catalytic systems, in understanding biological function (including effects on health), and in environmental remediation efforts. In all cases, these experimental studies are complemented by theoretical examinations of the same phenomena.

For transition metal cations, the oxidation of atomic iridium and platinum cations by sulfur dioxide were examined with energetics measured for generation of the metal monoxide, monosulfide, and oxysulfide cations. Hydration energies were measured for manganese dications (Mn2+) with four to ten water ligands. A review of our hydration studies focused on understanding the periodic trends in this thermochemistry.  

Research activity regarding biological molecules included examinations of the energetics for dissociation of several dipeptides containing asparagine, which is known to undergo deamidation (loss of ammonia), a process that has been linked to aging and the onset of neuro-degenerative diseases. Energetics for fragmentation of the GlyGlyAla and GlyProAla tripeptides, along with binding energies of sodium and potassium cations to the aliphatic amino acids. An important extension of these studies was realized by combining two instruments such that the decomposition energetics of selected conformers of protonated GlyProGlyGly tetrapeptide could be measured.

These traditional collisional and reaction studies were complemented by using infrared multiple photon dissociation (IRMPD) action spectroscopy at the Free Electron Lasers for Infrared eXperiments (FELIX) facility, Radboud University, The Netherlands. IRMPD was used to characterize species formed in CH bond activation reactions of methane with atomic third-row transition metal cations and small copper cluster cations. Structures of several complexes formed by sequential reactions of atomic platinum cations with methane were identified using IRMPD. Overlappin transition metal and biological chemistry, amino acid complexes of Zn2+ and Cd2+ were examined to provide structural information regarding why Zn binds preferentially to cysteine (Cys) and histidine (His) residues in biological systems and how the toxic Cd metal replaces it. IRMPD results for complexes of these metals to His and to the aromatic amino acids were published. In most cases, the metal binds to the amine and carbonyl groups of the backbone and the side-chain functional group. Comparisons of the complexes of Zn2+ and Cd2+ with His to those formed with Ca2+ and Ni2+ were also conducted.

In miscellaneous work, we published an IRMPD study of protonated unsymmetrical dimethylhydrazine (UDMH) and proton bound dimers of hydrazine and UDMH. Interesting dynamical restrictions were uncovered by combining an experimental study of reactions of CF3+ with CO and N2 along with a thorough theoretical exploration. Because of his expertise in transition metal chemistry, Prof. Armentrout was invited to collaborate with groups at T. U. Kaiserslautern on reactions and spectroscopy of Fen+(N2)m clusters and at U. Manchester on studies of metallosupramolecular rotaxanes.

In nearly all of these projects, graduate and undergraduate students participated in all phases of the research experience by acquiring the data, analyzing it, writing it up for publication, and presenting results orally or via posters at conferences. Theoretical studies that often accompany the experimental work are also carried out by students. Students engaged in this research project are gaining valuable experience in state-of-the-art physical and analytical methods, including techniques called guided ion beam tandem mass spectrometry and ion mobility spectrometry, along with IRMPD and quantum mechanical calculations. Several students engaged in international research by traveling to the Netherlands. During the course of this grant, three students completed their Ph.D. theses while supported by the National Science Foundation.
